official-title.#text: To authorize the Administrator of the Substance Abuse and Mental Health Services Administration, acting through the Director of the Center for Substance Abuse Treatment, to award grants to States to expand access to clinically appropriate services for opioid abuse, dependence, or addiction.

cosponsor.#text: Mr. Sean Patrick Maloney of New York

cosponsor.#tail: ) introduced the following bill; which was referred to the

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text: Expanding Opportunities for Recovery Act of 2014
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: Expanding Opportunities for Recovery Act of 2014

text.#text: This Act may be cited as the

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text: Administrator of the Substance Abuse and Mental Health Services Administration

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: (in this section referred to as the
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text: Director of the Center for Substance Abuse Treatment

text.#text: The

quote.#tail: ) shall award grants to States to expand access to clinically appropriate services for opioid abuse, dependence, or addiction.

text.#text: As conditions on the receipt of a grant under this section, a State shall agree to comply with the following:
The grant will be administered through the head of the State’s primary agency responsible for programs and activities relating to the treatment of substance abuse.
The services through the grant will be evidence-based such as medication-assisted treatment for substance use disorder.

The services through the grant will be provided according to a physician or a clinician’s recommendation to ensure that individuals receive the optimal level of substance use disorder treatment for the amount of time that is deemed medically necessary.
The services through the grant will be provided exclusively to individuals—
who lack health insurance; or
whose health insurance—
does not cover such services; or
places other barriers on the receipt of such services, such as—
limiting coverage of such services to a certain period of time; or

imposing non-quantitative treatment limitations that are more stringent than treatment limitations imposed on other medical conditions (such as a requirement to use less expensive services, like out-patient treatment, prior to more expensive, but physician-recommended services, such as in-patient or residential treatment).
The grant will not be used to pay or subsidize the cost of more than 60 consecutive days of opioid abuse, dependence, or addiction treatment in the case of any individual.

In expanding access to clinically appropriate services for opioid abuse, dependence, or addiction through a grant under this section, a State may provide for the use of medications, in conjunction with other treatment, so long as—
the medications are lawfully marketed under the

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text: Federal Food, Drug, and Cosmetic Act
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: Federal Food, Drug, and Cosmetic Act

text.#text: are clinically indicated to address the abuse, dependence, or addiction; and
are offered consistent with consumer choice.

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: shall coordinate the program under this section with the program for prevention and treatment of substance abuse under
